mn134:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn134:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn134:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
mn134:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
mn134:1.3.comm: Lomasakaṅgiya’s verse speaks of his determination to forge his way through the dense jungle in search of seclusion (Thag 1.27). He is probably also the same monk who appears in SN 54.12. His name means “hairy-limbs”.

mn134:2.1.pli: Atha kho candano devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ nigrodhārāmaṃ obhāsetvā yenāyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho candano devaputto āyasmantaṃ lomasakaṅgiyaṃ etadavoca:
mn134:2.1.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Candana, lighting up the entire Banyan Tree Monastery, went up to the Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya, and stood to one side. Standing to one side, he said to Lomasakaṅgiya:
mn134:2.1.comm: The god Candana, whose name means “sandalwood”, also appears at DN 20:10.5, DN 32:10.4, and SN 2:2.15.

mn134:2.2.eng: “Mendicant, do you remember the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night?”

mn134:2.3.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:2.4.pli: Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā”ti?

mn134:2.5.pli: “Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:2.6.pli: Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?
mn134:2.6.eng: But do you remember just the verses on the one who has one fine night?”

mn134:2.7.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.

mn134:2.10.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?
mn134:2.10.eng: “How do you remember the verses on the one who has one fine night?”

mn134:2.11.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, bhikkhu, samayaṃ bhagavā devesu tāvatiṃsesu viharati pāricchattakamūle paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ.
mn134:2.11.eng: “This one time, the Buddha was staying among the gods of the thirty-three at the root of the Shady Orchid Tree on the stone spread with a cream rug.
mn134:2.11.comm: This suggests that Candana was one of the Thirty-three. In the Chinese parallels, however, he heard this at Rājagaha. | Paṇḍukambala is a kind of luxury upholstery.

mn134:2.12.pli: Tatra bhagavā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsi:
mn134:2.12.eng: There he taught the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night to the gods of the thirty-three:

mn134:3.6.eng: you clearly discern in every case.

mn134:3.9.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn134:3.10.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn134:3.11.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn134:3.12.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn134:3.13.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn134:3.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn134:4.1.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.
mn134:4.1.eng: That’s how I remember the verses of the one who has one fine night.

mn134:4.2.pli: Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
mn134:4.2.eng: Learn the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night, mendicant,

mn134:4.3.pli: pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn134:4.4.pli: dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:4.5.pli: Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako”ti.
mn134:4.5.eng: It is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”

mn134:4.6.eng: That’s what the godling Candana said

mn134:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo tassā rattiyā accayena senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn134:5.1.eng: Then Lomasakaṅgiya set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.

mn134:5.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn134:5.2.eng: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:

mn134:5.3.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ sakkesu viharāmi kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.

mn134:5.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, aññataro devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ nigrodhārāmaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhante, so devaputto maṃ etadavoca:

mn134:5.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, taṃ devaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:

mn134:5.7.pli: ‘na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:5.8.pli: Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā’ti?

mn134:5.9.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:5.10.pli: Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā’ti?

mn134:5.11.pli: ‘Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.

mn134:5.14.pli: ‘Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā’ti?

mn134:5.15.pli: ‘Ekamidaṃ, bhikkhu, samayaṃ bhagavā devesu tāvatiṃsesu viharati pāricchattakamūle paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ.

mn134:5.16.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsi:

mn134:5.21.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.

mn134:5.22.pli: Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn134:5.23.pli: pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;

mn134:5.24.pli: dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.

mn134:5.25.pli: Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako’ti.

mn134:5.28.pli: Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca desetū”ti.
mn134:5.28.eng: “Sir, please teach me the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.”

mn134:6.1.eng: “But mendicant, do you know that god?”

mn134:6.2.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, bhante, jānāmi taṃ devaputtan”ti.

mn134:6.4.pli: Candano, bhikkhu, devaputto aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasikatvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti.
mn134:6.4.eng: Candana pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens to the teaching.
mn134:6.4.comm: Candana is here praised for his skill in learning, yet earlier he says that although he was present when the Buddha taught the “recitation passage and analysis”, he only remembered the verses (MN 134:2.12). As at MN 133:6.2, the parallels are more coherent, as they only mention him hearing the verses.

mn134:6.5.pli: Tena hi, bhikkhu, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn134:6.5.eng: Well then, mendicant, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn134:6.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavato paccassosi.

mn134:7.6.eng: you clearly discern in every case.

mn134:7.9.eng: Today’s the day to keenly work—

mn134:7.10.eng: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

mn134:7.11.eng: For there is no bargain to be struck

mn134:7.12.eng: with Death and his mighty horde.

mn134:7.13.eng: One who keenly meditates like this,

mn134:7.15.eng: that’s who has one fine night—

mn134:8-13.1.eng: And how do you run back to the past? … ”
mn134:8-13.1.comm: The Buddha goes on to repeat the analysis as in MN 131:4.1ff.

mn134:8-13.10.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.

mn134:8-13.11.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati …pe…

mn134:8-13.12.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.

mn134:14.17.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn134:14.18.pli: Attamano āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn134:14.18.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya approved what the Buddha said.

mn135:1.1.comm: This discourse has more parallels than any other Majjhima sutta: six in Chinese, two in Tibetan, two in Sanskrit, and fragments in Khotanese, Sogdian, and Tocharian. Its popularity is due to the detailed yet straightforward way it connects deeds with results, a subject of perennial fascination.

mn135:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane, anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn135:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn135:2.1.pli: Atha kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn135:2.1.eng: Then the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn135:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn135:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

mn135:3.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo yena manussānaṃyeva sataṃ manussabhūtānaṃ dissanti hīnappaṇītatā?
mn135:3.1.eng: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?

mn135:3.2.pli: Dissanti hi, bho gotama, manussā appāyukā, dissanti dīghāyukā;
mn135:3.2.eng: For people are seen who are short-lived and long-lived,

mn135:3.9.pli: Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo yena manussānaṃyeva sataṃ manussabhūtānaṃ dissanti hīnappaṇītatā”ti?
mn135:3.9.eng: What is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?”

mn135:4.1.pli: “Kammassakā, māṇava, sattā kammadāyādā kammayonī kammabandhū kammappaṭisaraṇā.
mn135:4.1.eng: “Student, sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.
mn135:4.1.comm: This phrase is also explained at AN 10.216. In AN 5.57 it is one of five sayings that should be frequently recollected by “a woman or a man, a layperson or a renunciate”.

mn135:4.2.eng: It is deeds that divide beings into

mn135:4.4.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
mn135:4.4.eng: “I don’t understand the meaning of what the worthy Gotama has said in brief, without explaining the details.

mn135:4.5.pli: Sādhu me bhavaṃ gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetu yathā ahaṃ imassa bhoto gotamassa saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ avibhattassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājāneyyan”ti.
mn135:4.5.eng: Worthy Gotama, please teach me this matter in detail so I can understand the meaning.”

mn135:4.6.pli: “Tena hi, māṇava, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn135:4.6.eng: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn135:4.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhagavato paccassosi.

mn135:5.1.pli: “Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā pāṇātipātī hoti luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.
mn135:5.1.eng: “Take some woman or man who kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
mn135:5.1.comm: The phrase “some woman or man” is used only here and in a few suttas that also deal with kamma (AN 3.70, AN 8.42, AN 8.43, AN 8.45). The mention of “woman or man” undercuts assumptions that women lack agency, or that their rebirth is lesser.

mn135:5.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:5.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

mn135:5.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati appāyuko hoti.
mn135:5.3.eng: If they’re not reborn in a place of loss, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re short-lived.
mn135:5.3.comm: Rebirth in the human realm is always due to good deeds in the past, but while in this realm, bad kamma can take effect. Of course, not all afflictions are caused by past kamma, a doctrine of the Jains that the Buddha rejected.

mn135:5.4.eng: For killing living creatures is the path leading to a short lifespan.

mn135:5.5.pli: pāṇātipātī hoti luddo lohitapāṇi hatapahate niviṭṭho adayāpanno pāṇabhūtesu.

mn135:6.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
mn135:6.1.eng: But take some woman or man who gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.

mn135:6.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:6.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn135:6.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati dīghāyuko hoti.
mn135:6.3.eng: If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re long-lived.

mn135:6.4.eng: For not killing living creatures is the path leading to a long lifespan.

mn135:6.5.pli: pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.

mn135:7.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā sattānaṃ viheṭhakajātiko hoti, pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā.
mn135:7.1.eng: Take some woman or man who habitually hurts living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.

mn135:7.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:7.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:7.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati bavhābādho hoti.
mn135:7.3.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re sickly …

mn135:7.5.pli: sattānaṃ viheṭhakajātiko hoti pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā.

mn135:8.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā sattānaṃ aviheṭhakajātiko hoti pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā.
mn135:8.1.eng: But take some woman or man who would never hurt living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.
mn135:8.1.comm: A reason for one of the Buddha’s marks (DN 30:2.7.2).

mn135:8.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:8.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …

mn135:8.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati appābādho hoti.
mn135:8.3.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re healthy …

mn135:8.5.pli: sattānaṃ aviheṭhakajātiko hoti pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā.

mn135:9.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā kodhano hoti upāyāsabahulo.
mn135:9.1.eng: Take some woman or man who is irritable and bad-tempered.

mn135:9.2.pli: Appampi vutto samāno abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patiṭṭhīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
mn135:9.2.eng: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
mn135:9.2.comm: A person with a “mind like an open sore” (AN 3.25:1.6).

mn135:9.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:9.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:9.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati dubbaṇṇo hoti.
mn135:9.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re ugly …

mn135:9.7.pli: appampi vutto samāno abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patiṭṭhīyati kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.

mn135:10.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā akkodhano hoti anupāyāsabahulo;
mn135:10.1.eng: But take some woman or man who isn’t irritable and bad-tempered.

mn135:10.2.pli: bahumpi vutto samāno nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patiṭṭhīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
mn135:10.2.eng: Even when heavily criticized, they don’t lose their temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

mn135:10.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:10.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …

mn135:10.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati pāsādiko hoti.
mn135:10.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re lovely …
mn135:10.4.comm: The text switches from vaṇṇavanta (“beautiful”, MN 135:3.4) to pāsādika (“lovely”).

mn135:10.7.pli: bahumpi vutto samāno nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patiṭṭhīyati na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.

mn135:11.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā issāmanako hoti;
mn135:11.1.eng: Take some woman or man who is jealous.

mn135:11.2.eng: They envy, resent, and begrudge the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others.

mn135:11.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:11.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:11.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati appesakkho hoti.
mn135:11.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re insignificant …

mn135:12.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā anissāmanako hoti;
mn135:12.1.eng: But take some woman or man who is not jealous …

mn135:12.2.pli: paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na issati na upadussati na issaṃ bandhati.

mn135:12.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:12.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …

mn135:12.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati mahesakkho hoti.
mn135:12.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re illustrious …

mn135:12.7.pli: paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na issati na upadussati na issaṃ bandhati.

mn135:13.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā na dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
mn135:13.1.eng: Take some woman or man who doesn’t give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

mn135:13.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:13.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:13.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati appabhogo hoti.
mn135:13.3.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re poor …

mn135:13.5.pli: na dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.

mn135:14.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
mn135:14.1.eng: But take some woman or man who does give to ascetics or brahmins …

mn135:14.2.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:14.2.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …

mn135:14.3.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati mahābhogo hoti.
mn135:14.3.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re rich …

mn135:14.5.pli: dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.

mn135:15.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā thaddho hoti atimānī—
mn135:15.1.eng: Take some woman or man who is obstinate and arrogant.

mn135:15.2.pli: abhivādetabbaṃ na abhivādeti, paccuṭṭhātabbaṃ na paccuṭṭheti, āsanārahassa na āsanaṃ deti, maggārahassa na maggaṃ deti, sakkātabbaṃ na sakkaroti, garukātabbaṃ na garukaroti, mānetabbaṃ na māneti, pūjetabbaṃ na pūjeti.
mn135:15.2.eng: They don’t bow to those they should bow to. They don’t rise up for them, offer them a seat, make way for them, or honor, respect, esteem, or venerate those who are worthy of such.
mn135:15.2.comm: The first three of these, phrased a little differently, are found at Pvr 7:51.1.

mn135:15.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:15.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:15.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati nīcakulīno hoti.
mn135:15.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in a low class family …

mn135:15.7.pli: abhivādetabbaṃ na abhivādeti, paccuṭṭhātabbaṃ na paccuṭṭheti, āsanārahassa na āsanaṃ deti, maggārahassa na maggaṃ deti, sakkātabbaṃ na sakkaroti, garukātabbaṃ na garukaroti, mānetabbaṃ na māneti, pūjetabbaṃ na pūjeti.

mn135:16.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā atthaddho hoti anatimānī;
mn135:16.1.eng: But take some woman or man who is not obstinate and arrogant …

mn135:16.2.pli: abhivādetabbaṃ abhivādeti, paccuṭṭhātabbaṃ paccuṭṭheti, āsanārahassa āsanaṃ deti, maggārahassa maggaṃ deti, sakkātabbaṃ sakkaroti, garukātabbaṃ garukaroti, mānetabbaṃ māneti, pūjetabbaṃ pūjeti.

mn135:16.3.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:16.3.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …

mn135:16.4.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati uccākulīno hoti.
mn135:16.4.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re reborn in an eminent family …

mn135:16.7.pli: abhivādetabbaṃ abhivādeti, paccuṭṭhātabbaṃ paccuṭṭheti, āsanārahassa āsanaṃ deti, maggārahassa maggaṃ deti, sakkātabbaṃ sakkaroti, garukātabbaṃ garukaroti, mānetabbaṃ māneti, pūjetabbaṃ pūjeti.

mn135:17.1.pli: Idha, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchitā hoti:
mn135:17.1.eng: Take some woman or man who doesn’t approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask:
mn135:17.1.comm: This is the duty of a wheel-turning monarch (DN 26:5.6), as well as being a reason for one of the Buddha’s marks (DN 30:1.25.3).

mn135:17.2.eng: ‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful?

mn135:17.3.eng: What is blameworthy and what is blameless?

mn135:17.4.eng: What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated?

mn135:17.5.pli: kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti?
mn135:17.5.eng: What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’

mn135:17.6.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:17.6.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …

mn135:17.7.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati duppañño hoti.
mn135:17.7.eng: or if they return to the human realm, they’re witless …

mn135:17.9.pli: samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā na paripucchitā hoti:

mn135:17.13.pli: kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti?

mn135:18.1.pli: Idha pana, māṇava, ekacco itthī vā puriso vā samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā paripucchitā hoti:
mn135:18.1.eng: But take some woman or man who does approach an ascetic or brahmin to ask:

mn135:18.2.eng: ‘Sir, what is skillful and what is unskillful?

mn135:18.3.eng: What is blameworthy and what is blameless?

mn135:18.4.eng: What should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated?

mn135:18.5.pli: kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti?
mn135:18.5.eng: What kind of action will lead to my lasting harm and suffering? Or what kind of action will lead to my lasting welfare and happiness?’

mn135:18.6.pli: So tena kammena evaṃ samattena evaṃ samādinnena kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
mn135:18.6.eng: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

mn135:18.7.pli: No ce kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, sace manussattaṃ āgacchati yattha yattha paccājāyati mahāpañño hoti.
mn135:18.7.eng: If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re very wise.

mn135:18.8.eng: For asking questions of ascetics or brahmins is the path leading to wisdom.

mn135:18.9.pli: samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā paripucchitā hoti:

mn135:18.13.pli: kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya hoti, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya hotī’ti?

mn135:19.1.pli: Iti kho, māṇava, appāyukasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā appāyukattaṃ upaneti, dīghāyukasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā dīghāyukattaṃ upaneti;
mn135:19.1.eng: So it is the way people live that makes them how they are, whether short-lived or long-lived,

mn135:19.2.pli: bavhābādhasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā bavhābādhattaṃ upaneti, appābādhasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā appābādhattaṃ upaneti;

mn135:19.3.pli: dubbaṇṇasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā dubbaṇṇattaṃ upaneti, pāsādikasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā pāsādikattaṃ upaneti;

mn135:19.4.pli: appesakkhasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā appesakkhattaṃ upaneti, mahesakkhasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā mahesakkhattaṃ upaneti;

mn135:19.5.pli: appabhogasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā appabhogattaṃ upaneti, mahābhogasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā mahābhogattaṃ upaneti;

mn135:19.6.pli: nīcakulīnasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā nīcakulīnattaṃ upaneti, uccākulīnasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā uccākulīnattaṃ upaneti;
mn135:19.6.eng: in a low class or eminent family,

mn135:19.7.pli: duppaññasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā duppaññattaṃ upaneti, mahāpaññasaṃvattanikā paṭipadā mahāpaññattaṃ upaneti.

mn135:20.1.pli: Kammassakā, māṇava, sattā kammadāyādā kammayonī kammabandhū kammappaṭisaraṇā.
mn135:20.1.eng: Sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.

mn135:20.2.eng: It is deeds that divide beings into

mn135:21.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, subho māṇavo todeyyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn135:21.1.eng: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,

mn135:21.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn135:21.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.

mn135:21.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn135:21.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
mn135:21.4.comm: He went for refuge first in MN 99:28.4 and subsequently in DN 10:2.37.9.

mn135:21.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn135:21.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
